body: Surely just a subclass with only config alias changed?
@samuelcolvin That's a minimal example, of course there are more fields in the real world model, but aliases are the only thing relevant for the problem/idea :)
Right, but your subclass still only needs one thing.
@samuelcolvin Sorry I'm not sure what you mean by this :( The subclass has a defined field `my_field` and a defined config, and it works fine as expected in REPL. Am I missing something else?
Sorry, I'm traveling will try to help tomorrow.

```py
from pydantic import BaseModel

class MyModel(BaseModel):
    my_field: int

class MyModelWithAlias(MyModel):
    class Config:
        fields = {'my_field': {'alias': 'myField'}}

print(MyModelWithAlias(myField=123))
print(MyModel(my_field=123))
```

Outputs:

```
MyModelWithAlias my_field=123
MyModel my_field=123
```

So create the class, then create a sub-class with just `Config` where you set the aliases. Would this work for you?

This isn't exactly what I originally suggested, it turns out you can't create `MyModel` then a sub-class `MyModelWithoutAliases` where `Config.fields` is blanked.

Another approach would be to use [`create_model`](https://pydantic-docs.helpmanual.io/#dynamic-model-creation).

I'll try to be more clear on what I'm trying to achieve :)

My service must receive and produce in a format e.g. `{"myField": 1}`.

Receiving data is fine: I'm parsing it as `MyModel(**input_dict)` and get an object instance with attribute `my_field`.

The main question/problem is about producing data. I want to construct Python objects using Python attribute names in arguments (something which could look like `MyModel.make(my_field=1)`), and then serialize it into a dict using `.dict(by_alias=True)` and receive a dict with key `myField`.
Thus the solution with subclass would not work, because I cannot create an instance using Python attribute names and serialize that same instance with aliases as keys.

Okay, this is #477. "Dump aliases" feel free to comment there.

Also mentioned in #576.

@samuelcolvin By saying "dump aliases" do you imply that I'll still have to declare two model classes? One for loading data from external sources (with "usual" aliases), and another one for creating from attributes and dumping (with "dump" aliases), even though logically they represent the same schema. My thought was that it could fit in one class with an alternative constructor or factory method.
